pros: My happiest day at Moffitt, was walking out on my last day.
cons: If you read about the Dark Triad and want to experience it along with all ten personality disorders at once, go work in Research at Moffitt. This is a great place to see leaders whose leadership skills are completely lacking collectively and subpar individually. Discrimination, bias, workplace bullying, retaliation, micromanaging, gaslighting, zero transparency, favoritism, nepotism, unprofessionalism, abusive behaviors, toxic environment abound. Human resources is vile and a huge part of the problem. Talk to an employment attorney before complaining to HR about anything. Before working there, research by reaching out to someone working currently in the area you are interested in on Linkedin and ask them for the truth about working there. Do not believe the good reviews. Work there at your own peril.

pros: The individuals who have a good work ethic work very hard. The staff in other departments (nursing, transportation, dietary, environmental) are rather pleasant. I cannot speak for any other location than the inpatient pharmacy.
cons: The management at Moffitt has created an environment toxic to be around. They do not listen to suggestions from the staff actually doing the daily activities, which in turn make for more tiresome work daily. You leave everyday feeling defeated and tired. There is no teamwork that occurs in the inpatient pharmacy. It is a dictator run department and if you have a voice and want to make things improve you are blacklisted and monitored under a microscope from drinking water to how long you use the restroom in an effort to terminate. The technicians in the department don't typically last more than a year at the inpatient pharmacy and those select few who have managed longer than a year are clearly dead inside. Upper management has no care for the lower man on pole. Everyone is replaceable in current management's eyes it seems.

pros: Discounted cancer treatment, and opportunity to work with patients
cons: Upper management was terrible. Had boots on the ground employees reporting to directors. Supervisors were unreachable due to their busy schedule, and left employees adrift. Their covid policies were not communicated to staff. They made us believe that anyone with a elevated temperature was not allowed into moffitt, but it turns out confirmed covid positive patients were permitted to come to moffitt clinic. They used valet, stopped in the cafeteria., and sat in waiting rooms, possibly exposing staff and other patients. They do not provide PPE to staff, but require us to see possible covid patients. When asked about PPE, my supervisor told me, “you don’t need it, unless they cough in your mouth, you’re fine”. Unsafe work environment with extremely close cubicles or shared offices with lax mask policies. Shuttle to parking was annoying and added 1 hour to work day. Unfair that higher paid employees never have to shuttle. They immediately get garage parking. The worst health insurance I’ve had in my entire career. High deductible, and no treatments or services are covered until deductible is met. No traditional copay’s here, you pay full price until you meet the deductible, then 20%-40% after. The most I’ve ever paid for health coverage in my life.

pros: Moffitt cares, not only about the patients, but also about their staff.  They have more "well-being" programs, etc., than I have ever encountered at a workplace.  90% of the staff have a positive attitude working at Moffitt.  The pay is great, I do not get benefits at this time because I am a temporary employee.  I am working towards becoming permanent.  In the time I have been at Moffitt, I cannot imagine working somewhere else.  The whole atmosphere is calm and stable.  Yes there is A LOT of work to do, but you WANT to do it, and you WANT to help the patients,  it is not drudgery at all!  I personally love working at Moffitt, the other employees I work with have been there for years, some 20 plus!  There is a reason for that and I see it.
cons: I cannot state any Cons at this time as I am grateful that I have a job, and not just a job at some corporate money making stressful crazy place (and I've seen many) but employment at one of the greatest cancer centers in the world.  I'm not just an employee either, I have a family member that is a patient, so I have been around the block at Moffitt.  I would say, if you work at Moffitt and wish to complain, you are in the wrong place, make the best of everything there is to offer there.  Be positive and realize that you are working under great management and in a wonderful, caring institution.

job_title: Research Coordinator II in Tampa, FL
pros: The work was rewarding and fit my interests well... I loved what I did and felt my work was appreciated by my superiors. It was a great place to learn and grow. Moffitt offers numerous opportunities for work-life balance and also seminars & lectures where employees can learn more about current research in their field. They actually had an impressive schedule of guest lecturers.
cons:
Working for a research company is a somewhat unique situation and Moffitt uses a dual-report system where employees report to an administrative supervisor and principle investiagor. There is sometimes a disconnect between employees and administrative supervisor. It can sometimes be frustrating to have to report to an admin spvsr who you feel didnt know you or the caliber of your work. But I also recognize the benefits to such a system to allow investigators to focus on their expertise and not have to deal with the bureaucratic nonsense.

I felt that I wasnt paid what my skills were worth when I was there... but don't we all? I worked there during the worst part of the recession and Moffitt was making serious cuts around the office (no coffee in the breakroom--couldnt even get your hands on a plastic fork!), but the employees recognized that times were hard and I think it was appreciated that these cuts were made rather than letting employees go.

pros: Relaxed atmosphere. Staff is diverse and teams work well.

review_title: I have worked here many, many years and now I am looking to leave
pros: The relationships that you can build with other facilities and some coworkers is invaluable. The medical benefits package is pretty good.
cons: It is very sad to see the favoritism that is present throughout the organization in the clinics and management. I believe the Motto "The workers will always work and the slackers will always slack" is more and more prominent. There is NO accountability and if you try to speak up about it, you become the trouble maker. They say that Retaliation is against HR policy but then Retaliation becomes the EXACT punishment when you try to speak up when treated unfairly. Managers allow unacceptable behavior to go on daily and again, to speak up about it means you are the trouble maker. This all is just the tip of the Iceberg. It TRULY saddens me to be at this place of employment for almost 20 years and now have to look for another job outside of the institution because of the corruption that has flooded the institution and NO ONE is willing to make the necessary changes to fix it.

review_title: Physician turnover rate is very high for a reason!
pros: Adequate compensation compared to other academic institutions but way below what is deserved given that physicians are expected to see private practice type numbers of patients
cons:
Physicians are treated very poorly here. Every function (nursing, scheduling, infusion center, electronic medical records department, advertising group) is allowed to give the physicians orders and directives and they are expected to comply. The physician management is primarily surgeons and they do not understand the needs of medical oncologists. The physician turnover rate is so high that some patients end up seeing 6 different doctors (of the same specialty) within 1-2 years. That is very bad for patient care. The physician management and HR look the other way when unprofessional behavior and even frank verbal abuse occur. In my opinion, this is a very bad place to work for junior faculty (there is no mentorship at all and you are expected to see private practice numbers of patients while doing your research on the nights and weekends, resulting in routine 80+ hour work weeks) and for women. There are very few women in leadership (both physician and otherwise). It is clear that senior management does not care for their employees and focuses primarily on financial outcomes. For example, the child care center at Moffitt was abruptly closed with only 2 months notice to make room for additional faculty offices. 
Prospective physicians (especially fellows), investigate the rate of turnover in your department and talk to former employees before taking a job here.

pros: Reputation in the community and work with purpose.
cons: Disorganized culture with multiple broken systems that ‘support ‘ the infrastructure...which constantly break, thus its difficult to do  jobs efficiently. review_title: HR and Sr. Mgmt are a joke/Employee morale is in the toilet
pros: It used to be a great place to work, with every employee happy to be there and contributing to the prevention and cure of cancer.  That was in mid 2000.
cons: "More with less" is the mantra.  If you press your boss for that promotion they promised after years of "exceeds expectations" and making them look good (by taking all credit for your work), then you suddenly get re-assigned, re-evaluated (as a poor performer), and shown the door. Going to HR is a joke, because all they do is inform your manager you have a problem with them.  Going to Sr. Mgmt is a joke, because they are all poorly trained in how to effectively manage people.  This happens in every department in all of Moffitt.  Anything that looks like a nail is quickly hammered down.  I hope Alan List is able to change this systemic mentality.  For an institution dedicated to curing cancer... they certainly allow malignant people to persist as managers.  If you need a job, fine.  If you want a career, look elsewhere.

pros: I work in research and thought that Moffitt would be an excellent company to work for in a field I have a passion for. I was obviously wrong after learning how unprofessional management and HR was.
cons: I had two interviews/meetings with hiring managers for a Research Coordinator Position at Moffitt Cancer Center. Afterwards there was little to no communication regarding the opportunity from HR or the hiring managers. I called several times to multiple people following up about the position and everyone was considerably rude. HR did not give me the time of day and whenever I actually got a hold of a manager, they spoke to me as if I was inconveniencing them trying to get more information on a position THEY called me in previously for. I declined the offer I received from there months after a decision was supposed to be made considering they wasted a lot of my time, and I regret applying there. Luckily I received an offer from USF, who was much more informative and professional to work with. Overall it was an awful experience and I will gladly tell any peers I have who potentially would want to work at Moffitt to not bother wasting their time.

pros: Organization is OK, Blind following blind, somehow the system is working. May be because of excess of state and federal funding !
cons: So much efforts to raise charity via Miles for Moffitt but more than what is raised is wasted in poor planning,  constant renovations in almost all departments, departments are consistently moving from one building to another.  A lot of wastage--no good supervision of departmental finances.

job_title: Clinical Trial Coordinator in Tampa, FL
pros: The patients truly appreciate the work you do for them. It's rapidly growing and expanding to new locations. I know that people in some of departments love working at Moffitt, but I wouldn't say that sentiment is universal.
cons: Communication is inconsistent. In this role we work with multiple departments and one department gets told that a new process in going to be implemented, but the other departments that are also going to be effected by the new implementation don't receive information about the change until after the fact or once a problem arises due to the new change. On the opposite extreme we receive a ton of communications from Moffitt, but it's not that useful. Also there isn't a clear promotional structure in the Clinical Trials Office for advancement and as a coordinator you're only options for advancement are as a higher level coordinator unless you try to venture into upper management.

review_title: I have been at Moffitt for several years and truly believe they consistently work towards their mission and goals.
pros: Moffitt Cancer Center is a fast growing company with plenty of room for growth if your a motivated individual.  If you work for a team that is properly staffed, you will also be able to benefit from a reasonable work/life balance.
cons: Moffitt is a very bureaucratic organization with a great deal of political nonsense that can often prevent teams from being productive.  If you are lucky to work for a good leader who is willing to listen to their employees you will find the place rewarding.  The benefits have gone down-hill over the past 6 years.  The company no longer values the employees like they used to.

pros: Excellent environment,  always room for advancement from withing. Great management.
cons:
Healthcare driven budget causes constant change in support process and organization of teams and structure which can unravel large amounts of work in a short time. Constantly having to restart work that you just finished before you can implement the change and prove it would have worked.
-some managers in IT have healthcare backgrounds and the mindset of such folks doesn't always understand the IT way of doing things.

review_title: Okay place to work... With some caveats
pros: Flexible hours (at least in research they are); decent pay (usually about mid-range for comparable positions across the US); okay benefits; large well-known organisation with good mission.
cons: They are all about who you know and how close you (or your manager) is with the senior management. I call it "Big Boy's Club" (and I have 7+ years of experience to support that statement). Also, your pay will very much depend on that too (I know people got paid 20% more for exactly the same position, because their boss was close to the "Big Boys"). They say that there is "market analysis" to support the pay which is true, but of course there are endless ways to bend that truth if need be.

pros: Flexible schedule, co-workers that really work together.  Patient's that appreciate what we do. Feeling like you are making a difference.
cons: Benefits have shrunk year over year.  Clinical Ladder is unbelieveably complicated and requires way too much to maintain level.  If you don't meet requirements, you are dropped a level and suffer at least a 5% pay cut, possibly more if you are placed in the low end of a lower level.  Lack of adequate staffing.  High nursing turnover.  Management does not understand what the nurses do, or how hard they work.  Low pay.

review_title: Started off great but went downhill..

review_title: Postdocs are a second class citizen in Moffitt
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Tampa, FL
pros: Some great Principal Investigators trying to make a change
cons: As a hospital, Moffitt takes care first of its Medical Doctors, and then it takes care of its Staff (including Nurses, Principal Investigators, and administrative staff). If you are a postdoctoral researcher in Moffitt, you are a second class citizen. You are considered a "temporary employee", and don't have the benefits that full time staff have, and you depend on soft money.  Some principal investigators do try to keep the high morale of postocs by supporting them through the postdoc association, and moral support in general.  But PI's are also very constrained by money, as NIH funds dry out for Moffitt and as Moffitt $ support for research vanishes.

review_title: Great the first 5 years but then Moffitt's leadership has gone down hill for all employees.
pros: Great retirement,  good motive to put patients first.  Worked with some good people over the years.  Employee acute clinic.
cons: Employees are overworked,  underpaid, leadership doesn't care about the concerns/issues employees address to them. Horrible health insurance.  All they talk about is cost savings and how to continue to cut money in each department.  However leadership constantly spending on other meaningless things.  Huge turnover last 5 years,we lost good doctos,app,nurses,etc from these same issues! No flexible work arrangements available. Work/ life balance is horrible now.  Dont recommend for working parents as they care less if you have children.

review_title: Declining as an industry  Leader and as a  quality healthcare facility.
pros: Quality hard working  employees who strive to make it all work. Reasonable Pay.
cons: Terrible benefits, worse every year. Obsession with image, the best staff are leaving or forced out for cheaper, younger staff who cost less but look good on paper. Care quality a constant struggle to maintain for those of us who are left. Chronic understaffing. Abuse of staff by doctors who care little about following the rules.

review_title: Outstanding People and Great Mission; Don't Promote From Within and Low Salary
pros: Most of the people that work for Moffitt are wonderful! They truly care about the patients and their co-workers. I felt like I was making a difference when I went into work everday even though I rarely had patient contact.
cons: The salary is low and they rarely promote from within. It seems a lot of the issues are from lower management and HR. The CEO is trying to foster positive change, but HR and the lower level managers seem to be stuck in their ways.

pros: Moffitt is a very friendly comfortable place to work.  I am a Management Asst to a Nursing Director and I really love my boss and my job.  There is no micro managing and I can work independently to get the job done.  All the staff are great to work with and Moffitt has such a great diverse population of staff who are here to take care of the patients.
cons: Sometimes stressful.  Health benefits could be better.

review_title: ICU Nurse - Great place to work
pros: The staffing ratios are pretty great all around - 2 to 1 in ICU (often 1-1). Pay seems decent compared to other hospitals in general. Since physicians are directly associated with Moffitt it's fairly easy to get in touch with them. I've never had to call an off-site office for a provider, they are always a page away and most have been great to work with.
cons: No extra critical care pay. Staying well staffed is great for ratios but very little opportunity for extra shifts (even when it isn't overtime). IAll in all you have very sick patients. You have the same level of care as other ICUs except if you save them from their acute event whatever that may be, they still have cancer when it's all said and done and you have to be ready to face that.

pros: Meaningful work, wonderful patients and physicians.
cons: Management hires nurses with no oncology experience and no desire to learn.  Less than 25% of RN's are OCN which is ridiculous in a cancer hospital.  Understaffed.  Do not value long term employees.  High turn over rate.  Lack of training for Clinical Research Coordinators.  Management oblivious to issues at the ground level.  Research pharmacy is VERY understaffed and an accident waiting to happen.

pros: The organization provides a lot of perks such as discounted tickets for Tampa Bay professional sports teams and theme parks. I also have had the opportunity of taking advantage of a flexible work schedule as well.
cons: Well the organization is a non-profit so don't expect getting paid a lot of money unless you are an upper level executive, or a medical professional. The internal customer service between employees can be better.

job_title: Inpatient Pharmacy Technician in Tampa, FL
pros:
—A very faster pace environment, but I liked my job. Moffit cross trains all techs in all areas, so you have a variety of tasks instead of the same old same.. From Pyxis Delivery to pulling narcs to making chemo.
— Working with some great pharmacists and other pharmacy techs.
— management really tries to work with people schedules.
cons:
— not competitive pay. They pay less then other hospitals in the area by a lot! 
— There is a lot of animosity between shifts, and feels like working with a bunch of high schoolers... There is often fighting between techs.. 
—- Lack of leadership means a lot of work is dumped on a few people instead of everyone doing their fairshare..

job_title: Research Specialist II in Tampa, FL
pros: Big company; training opportunities; internship opportunities; interacting with multiple departments; good benefits; detailed employee handbook; helpful HR department. The biggest asset to my career was being at such a large institution, where I could see many different career trajectories and get a better idea of what would fit for me.
cons: The research departments are run very poorly with bad management. Moffitt talks about promoting from within as a perk for working with them, but they promote unqualified individuals into leadership positions without training them, rather than hire external, experienced candidates.

review_title: Dishonest company to work for. Dont turn your back!
pros: I loved caring for the Patients and benefits were ok.
cons: HR Department is so terrible, unless you are high up in the ranks, your opinion does not matter. They will terminate you for no good reason even lies. as i have said your voice dose not matter. You are not safe working here. My advice, dont invest years with this company !

pros: I have the best job. I have the opportunity to share connections with amazing patients and staff everyday.  I am truly blessed to offer hope and encouragement and make a difference in someone else's life. I do gain courage from my patients. I am inspired by their strength and hope I am providing them the support all of us need and deserve.
cons: Emotional fatigue. You must have coping mechanisms to share in some of the patients struggles but Moffitt has resources to handle this. My team will always find a way to carry on and find the courage to support one another.

job_title: Research Associate II in Tampa, FL
pros: Personally love working for Moffitt especially for the Lab that I am in now. Benefits are great
cons: The pay is not really competitive and its hard to get a raise as HR decides not your PI. Parking a a hassle, you have to park off campus and take a shuttle to the main building

review_title: Not-for Profit with a For-Profit mentality
pros: Nice location, shared location with University of South Florida,
cons: Office policies are ridiculous.  The leadership is non-visible, in their offices, while the rest of the people sit in these dark cubicles (unless you are working in a research lab, then you have windows).  Corporate culture trumps anything else.  For example, there used to be water coolers which were removed to cut cost, but coffee machines are still available, as is free coffee.

job_title: Research Associate I in Tampa, FL
pros: Decent benefits. Wellness program is great, offering on-site blood draws for health evaluations (free) to wellness fairs and discounts on health insurance of participating.
cons: Other benefits cut every year (PTO caps etc).  Have to pay for parking. Lack of communal area for research personnel, which I think I contributes to the lack of interdepartmental collaboration on campus. Unfortunately a lot of that is due to space challenges as we have limited area on campus. A lot of bureaucratic loopholes to jump through and lazy administration sometimes and offices for essential personnel can be at satellite buildings (have to drive for HR appointments!)

review_title: Heavy on process; disorganized and dishonest management
pros:
Excellent flexible work arrangement possibilities for some IT staff--work from home one or more days per week, or have a compressed work week (i.e. work more hours a few days per week or pay period and have one weekday per week or pay period off).  

Very good pay for certain positions. 

Fairly generous time-off accrual and a PTO 'cash-in' option mean one rarely can't take time off or benefit financially from not taking time off.

The environment is fairly casual with respect to expectations. Anybody with any competence is very likely to find it easy to appear much more capable than his co-workers (but: see the 'con' re: tolerance of inferior performance for why).
cons:
The benefits package underwent a huge downward 'adjustment' in the 2012/2013 year; I would rate them at well below average

Communication from the executive level down to the lowest supervisor is painfully absent. Frequently direct supervisors and their immediate supervisors provide conflicting information regarding policies or new initiatives.

Within my department it is clear that the managers and their director are frequently on completely separate pages. I have been told two different things by my supervisor and his boss on more than one occasion. It is also very clear that my immediate supervisor, his peers and their boss do not have a unified direction in mind for the department. There is nothing that binds our teams together, or even that binds the individuals on my team, to work toward a common goal, so I often find myself wondering why we're organized the way we are. I work directly with individuals in other teams and departments, and it seems this isn't just my department.

There is a high tolerance for continued inferior performance and competence among management and non-management alike. I often find myself thinking it's subconsciously deliberate so that an environment of expected mediocrity is the norm: that's demoralizing. Compounding this is a glib and ready hand to hint at the prospect for promotion, but it always seems to be "6 to 8 months" down the road.

review_title: Great for the first 2.5 years. After that it went down hill.
job_title: Leiter Einkauf / Stellvertretender Betriebsleiter in Tampa, FL
pros: The overall atmosphere of Moffitt is very pleasant. The people who work there are very nice and we're like one big family.
cons: Unfortunately, it was managment and two to be exact. It speaks volumes when within 3 years one department went through 12 upper management.

pros: The patients are a joy to work with.
cons: Condescending employees, and management. Terrible work life balance because they expect you to study on your days off. I graduated with honors yet when I go into work I get quizzed and if I don’t know the answer and made to feel like I’m a complete idiot. If I ask a question I get laughed  at and told “you should already know this.” Parking is terrible and you have to pay for it.

review_title: Good start for those wanting to enter the clinical research field.

pros: Giving best customer service to patients.  Co-Workers are great team mates fun to work with we help each other.

Don't care if you are sick you get written up, occurrences.  If you make you employees happy they will give you 100 percent. Favoritism towards certain employees.  Employees sleeping on the job same one everyday.  Hard workers don't get recognized.

job_title: Research Specialist I in Tampa, FL
pros: Good culture, diversity, team building, Higher pay compared to same position in other hospitals.
cons: Poor management (too much micro management), bad communication between departments, repetitive errors made by peers, alot of nepotism, If you are an important asset to the department management will block you from transferring to other departments with what ever means necessary (even writing you up for some petty issues will set you back 6 months in the same department).

pros: PTO, 4 weeks of vacation your 1st year, Merritt raise hits every January, 2nd raise is annual raise every July, Health, Dental Vision, 401K, The patients make your job worth while no matter what dept you work in, A life changing place to work at.

job_title: Patient Placement Representative in Tampa, FL
pros: Schedule is extremely flexible, management is very relaxed about scheduling as long as one person is present to cover.
cons: Horrible software system, horrible executive leadership. There are metrics and data logs for every single thing possible because the system(s) in place cannot pull data/metrics themselves. Very inefficient, lots of human error.

pros: Great care for cancer patients. Staff really concerned for patients well being.
cons: Understaffed, overworked,  promised more help that never happened.  Additional physician  with no additional support staff. Management sleeps their way to the top running around with dresses so short totally unprofessional.  Some departments much better than others.

pros: Flex time, educational reimbursment and a team that is committed to the mission of the cancer center are all empowering and motivating. It's rare that you meet a team member who is not happy here.
cons: Emotionally draining due to the nature of the beast. And for those who are not medically trained, it can take awhile to learn the verbiage used in a medical setting.

pros: The ONLY good thing about working as a researcher at Moffitt is they do have very good seminar talks. Moffitt provides research seminars several times per week which are highly educational especially for cancer immunotherapy. Thus, you have a great opportunity to because educated with top notch cancer research, BUT you have to be willing to put up with the horrible/toxic social environment there.
cons: There were so many cons about working there, I will do my best to try and list them all. I resigned as soon as my contract ended and already had another job lined up. First off, they forced me to be shuttled in on a bus from my parking for 1 year before they gave me parking "near" the  building I work in. Even then, it was still a block walk and I had to pay $1000/ year for the parking space. Riding a junky bus for a year before and after work when you have a PhD is absolutely insulting and unacceptable. It was horrible waiting for the shuttle bus in the rain, or when it was 95 deg F, and when I was tired from a long day at work. The social work environment is toxic. People are all stuck up and snobby. Barely anybody is friendly and people don't even look at each other in the hallway, let alone simply smile or god forbid act civil and say "hi". Many professors have MAJOR superiority complexes. When you go to seminars, only the high up people are (unofficially) allowed to sit at the front of the room. It's ridiculous and asinine to exclude and discourage young fresh minds such as grad students and postdocs from sitting in the front so that they can more readily be involved in the talk. The research equipment is severely lacking and what is there is always broken and takes forever to finally get fixed. You have to walk to different buildings and different floors just get an experiment done, and because they have way too many people using a small amount of equipment, a lot of times the machine is already taken when you get there with your samples ready. The equipment is often dirty, old, and/or broken. A ton of unprofessional and unacceptable things happen behind the scenes, but even when informed they just brush it all under the rug so the professors face no consequences and know they can basically get away with anything. They are also a greedy company. They say they are nonprofit, and pay the researchers crap for salary, but then I frequently saw doctors that work there pulling out of their cushy parking spots in their Maseraties! (ridiculous). Another example of their greediness, they make you pay back taxes on your own health insurance and daycare. When I did my taxes, I had to pay several thousand dollars of my tax money for my Moffitt health insurance and daycare. At most companies (that are not greedy) the company is suppose to cover the insurance tax for their employees, but nope not at Moffitt. Its the only place I've ever worked that did that. Unfortunately, most of the people who work there are way more concerned with their social status, how they are dressed, and what everyone looks like than actually doing good cancer research and helping people. Its sad and pathetic to me. I honestly felt like I was back in high school working there, with cliques and popularity contests. On top of that, you can constantly see the high up people having their expensive "receptions" on the bottom atrium floor with their fancy foods and top shelf liquors/drinks. Really!? Maybe if you spent less money on your expensive parties for your suits and ties, you could invest that money into your subpar research facility to fix all the broken equipment and get more equipment so its not always taken when people need to get their experiments done. Poor management for sure. Basically, the research sector of Moffitt is just for show so that they can get NIH/NCI comprehensive cancer center designation, but they really only care about the hospital sector because they charge the patients so much money for treatment that's where they make all their money. They are super bureaucratic and treat you like a number not a human being. Forced annual fluhots (there was talk of biannual when I left), forced blood tests and drug tests for preemployment even when you don't work with patients. Working at Moffitt was a horrible experience and everyday I couldn't wait to not work there anymore. It's not worth the toll it takes on your mental sanity, especially for such crap salary. Don't waste your time, there are way better places to work. Life is short, don't settle.

pros: Worked as an intern on a project team in the health outcomes and behavior department. It was a great work environment, with friendly staff, PI and fellow student interns. We had the opportunity to contribute by collaborating on mini research assignments and attending events.
